title: Jacob K. McPherson
text:
Welcome to my personal website! I’m Jacob K. McPherson, and this is where I share my research, thoughts, and professional activities.


Check out my latest blog posts for insights and updates on my work.




About Me - Learn more about my background and interests
Research - Explore my research projects and publications
Talks - See my presentations and conference talks
Podcasts - Listen to my podcast appearances
Gallery - View photos and media from my work




Feel free to reach out if you’d like to connect or collaborate!

title: GitHub Actions Deployment Setup
text:
This document explains the comprehensive GitHub Actions setup for automatic deployment of the Quarto website to GitHub Pages.


Two GitHub Actions workflows have been implemented:


Triggers: - Push to main or master branch - Pull requests to main or master branch (for testing) - Manual trigger via workflow dispatch
Jobs:



OS: Ubuntu Latest
Steps:

Checkout repository
Setup Quarto (latest release)
Configure GitHub Pages
Render Quarto project to HTML
Upload Pages artifact from docs/ directory






Environment: github-pages
Conditions: Only runs on main/master branch pushes
Dependencies: Requires build job to complete successfully
Action: Deploy to GitHub Pages using the built artifact

Permissions: - contents: read - Read repository contents - pages: write - Write to GitHub Pages - id-token: write - Write identity tokens for deployment
Concurrency: - Group: “pages” - Cancel in progress: false (allows deployments to complete)




Triggers: - Manual trigger via workflow dispatch - Pull requests that modify: - _quarto.yml configuration - *.qmd content files - GitHub Actions workflows
Purpose: - Validates Quarto configuration - Tests rendering process without deployment - Provides early feedback on content changes







Project Type: Website
Output Directory: docs/ (required for GitHub Pages)
Format: HTML with Cosmo theme




Enhanced to exclude Quarto-specific files: - /.quarto/ - Quarto cache directory - *_cache/ - Rendering cache directories - .quarto - Additional Quarto files - _site/ - Alternative output directory - *.tmp - Temporary files - .DS_Store, Thumbs.db - OS-specific files





Developer pushes changes to main/master branch
Build job triggers and:

Sets up fresh Ubuntu environment
Installs Quarto
Renders all .qmd files to HTML in docs/
Uploads the docs/ directory as Pages artifact

Deploy job triggers (only on main/master) and:

Downloads the artifact
Deploys to GitHub Pages
Makes site live at https://jacobkmcpherson.github.io






Automated Deployment: No manual steps required
Version Control: All source files tracked in Git
Build Validation: PRs are tested before merge
Consistent Environment: Same Quarto version used for all builds
Rollback Capability: Can revert to any previous commit
Concurrent Safety: Only one deployment at a time





Build failures: Check the Actions tab for detailed logs
Deployment failures: Verify GitHub Pages is enabled in repository settings
Content issues: Use the validation workflow to test changes




For this to work, the repository needs: 1. GitHub Pages enabled with source set to “GitHub Actions” 2. Actions permissions enabled 3. Branch protection (optional but recommended) for main/master branch

title: Welcome to My Blog
text:
This is my first blog post on my new Quarto website. I’m excited to share my thoughts, research insights, and experiences here.


In future posts, I’ll be writing about:

My research work and findings
Professional insights and experiences

Thoughts on industry trends
Personal reflections




Be sure to check back regularly for new content, and feel free to reach out if you have questions or want to discuss any of the topics I cover!
